cmes.note: Very faint narrow CME with two or three consecutive fronts (maybe the earliest one is a narrow shock), which is seen directly to the W in SOHO LASCO C2, and very faintly seen in C3. It is not seen in GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2. No clear source for this event has been found in EUV imagery, so it is most likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is not seen in STEREO A imagery and its source has not been found in EUV imagery, so only a plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

cmes.note: CME/streamer blowout with a very faint, fuzzy front seen to the SW in STEREO A COR2 and in SOHO LASCO C3. Its start is likely earlier, as in early COR2 and C3 timestamps this faint front is very hard to trace and it is not clearly seen in C2. The CME is obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. No source has been found for this CME in EUV imagery, so it is likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate, speculative analysis based on an approximate fit of the very faint, fuzzy, uncertain front in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3.

cmes.note: A relatively bright narrow CME seen to the NNW in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1), partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. Its source may be a minor eruption right behind the NW limb as seen (rather unclearly) in SDO AIA/GOES SUVI 304. Minor opening of field lines are also seen behind the limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2026-02-07T09:00Z. This eruption is most clearly seen in STEREO A EUV 195 as slowly developing dimming centered around (N35W90) starting after 2026-02-07T09:00ZZ.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1) and confirmed by the location of the minor source eruption seen mostly in STEREO A EUVI 195 as minor dimming. There seems to be a northern deflection from the source location.

cmes.note: Faint CME to the NNW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 (partially obscured by pylon in C3), directed to the N in STEREO A COR2A, following and overlapping with 2026-02-07T09:36Z CME. No clear source found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based solely on the fit of the faint, fuzzy front in all three coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1). No clear source has been found in EUV imagery.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2026-02-07T16:38Z. The potential source may be seen as moving field lines in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA starting around 2026-02-07T19:21Z. A possible far-sided source candidate may be a region of interest seen in NSO GONG data, which may be former Active Region 14341, located approximately around longitude -145.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the potential source location in NSO GONG data.
Measurement of the wider, fainter shock feature.

cmes.note: Faint CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1, preceding CME: 2026-02-07T23:00Z. The CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a real-time data gap starting at 2026-02-07T16:38Z and is obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. There is no clear source seen in EUV imagery, and the CME is likely farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1. The CME is obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 and not visible in STEREO A COR2 in real-time due to a data gap starting at 2026-02-07T16:38Z. The potential source is a filament eruption, with liftoff best seen starting around 2026-02-07T21:00Z in GOES SUVI 304. Dimming can also be seen centered around N25W60 in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location using available SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-08T08:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is field line opening/movement seen originating from the vicinity of AR14373 (N09E52) beginning at approx. 2026-02-08T07:04Z as seen in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-08T15:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 likely due to it being directly far sided with respect to STEREO A. The source of this event is field line opening seen along the SE limb beginning around 2026-02-08T14:12Z as seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of E90 due to source near the limb and lack of triangulation. Longitude fits are between E45 and E130.

cmes.note: Faint CME seen along a NNE streamer first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-08T16:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. The source of this event is a small filament eruption seen along the NNE limb in SDO AIA 304 beginning around 2026-02-08T15:44Z, along with field line opening and post eruptive dimming seen in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2.

cmes.note: Faint minor CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and a couple of early C3 images before it dissipates. The CME is possibly covered by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1 (or too faint to be seen in this coronagraph); it is covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A COR2. Its source could be a minor opening of field lines on/behind the SW limb at the time seen in SDO AIA 193/304/131, and movement of field line behind the SW limb seen in GOES SUVI 284, however this is not a definitive source.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is fully covered by the daily data gap in STEREO A COR2 and no clear source has been found for it in EUV imagery. Plane-of-sky analysis is the only possible analysis; it is based on SOHO LASCO imagery.

cmes.note: Faint narrow CME/jet seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. It is fully covered by the night time data gap in STEREO A COR2. No clear source has been found in EUV imagery for this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME is fully covered by the night time data gap in STEREO A COR2. No source for this CME has been found in EUV imagery. Therefore, only plane-of-sky analysis is possible, using SOHO LASCO imagery.

cmes.note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not clearly visible in GOES CCOR-1. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2026-02-08T18:23Z to 2026-02-09T03:38Z, and the CME is not visible in the available imagery. The potential source may be an eruption with dimming centered around N15W50 best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2026-02-08T23:04Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. Limited available imagery was used, as the CME's leading edge fades away quickly.

cmes.note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2026-02-08T18:23Z to 2026-02-09T03:38Z, and the CME is not visible in available imagery. The potential source is an eruption on the east limb seen around latitude N10. The eruption is best seen as opening field lines in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA and GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2026-02-09T00:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location on the east limb. Due to the uncertainty in the source eruption location, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-09T23:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2026-02-09T18:53Z to 2026-02-10T03:38Z. The source of this CME is a C9.2 flare from Active Region 14374 (N10E75) which peaked at 2026-02-09T23:02Z, along with a small amount of associated filament ejecta exhibiting a heavy Southern deflection. This flare is visible in SDO AIA 131, along with field line movement seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and ejecta visible in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-10T09:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to being directly far sided with respect to the STEREO A spacecraft. The source of this event is a small eruption from Active Region 14374 (N11E67) which began around 2026-02-10T09:14Z as seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit on SOHO LASCO C2 and GOE CCOR-1. This feature appears to exhibit a strong Northern deflection.

cmes.note: This narrow CME is faintly seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-02-10T19:38Z. It is briefly seen in SOHO LASCO C3 before becoming too faint to track. It is not clearly seen in GOES CCOR-1. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR during this event. The source for this CME appears to be a small and narrow filament eruption with associated moving/opening field lines visible in SDO/AIA 304, 171, and 193; as well as in GOES SUVI 284, to the SW along the limb starting around 2026-02-10T19:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on potential source location area and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery. This is specifically measuring the most narrow portion of the feature visible in difference imagery. There is a much slower, slightly wider portion that may also be associated with this source that measured with speeds below 150 km/s. The longitude of this CME may vary by +/- 10 degrees due to limited stereoscopic viewpoints of the source location.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding sources seen on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to an eruption from former Active Region 14358, which was located at approximately N17W128 based on the rate of solar rotation, starting around 2026-02-11T09:15Z seen in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the northwest limb in STEREO A EUVI 195 imagery at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location. As this event is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 or GOES CCOR-1 coronagraphs, a triangulated measurement was not available for this event. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the north in STEREO A COR2 imagery and to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. The source for this event is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: This CME is visible to the northwest in STEREO A COR2, SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-11T17:48Z, as well as by GOES CCOR-1 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which began at 2026-02-11T17:38Z, and is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 as it's obscured by the pylon. The source of this event is a small field line opening seen along the NW limb in GOES SUVI 195 beginning at approx. 2026-02-11T17:04Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of W90 due to source near the limb and lack of STEREO A COR2 to triangulate.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2026-02-11T00:48Z. This CME is currently only visible in SOHO LASCO C2 due to data gaps in STEREO A COR2 (beginning at 2026-02-11T17:38Z) and SOHO LASCO C3 (beginning at 2026-02-12T01:30Z). This event is also directed into the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. The source of this CME is a filament eruption and field line opening seen originating from on or just beyond the SW limb beginning at approx. 2026-02-12T00:25Z in GOES SUVI 195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary plane-of-sky using early frames of SOHO LASCO C2 imagery.

cmes.note: Narrow CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-02-12T06:36Z. The CME is also faintly seen to the NE in GOES CCOR-1 for a couple frames but is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3. The CME is also covered by a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. There is no discernible source on the Earth-facing disk, so the source is most likely far-sided. It is also possibly outflow following earlier activity to the NE.

cmeAnalyses.note: Uncertain plane-of-sky measurement due to lack of available triangulation and lack of source signature.

cmes.note: Narrow, jet-like CME first seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2026-02-12T13:26Z. The CME is also seen to the NW in GOES CCOR-1 but is obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. The CME is also covered by a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely an eruption near the NW limb beginning around 2026-02-12T12:39Z. The associated filamentary ejecta is best seen in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on visible source location near the NW limb (W90).

cmes.note: CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-02-12T13:36Z. This CME is also seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1. It is covered by a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely outflow following earlier activity to the NE.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement chosen due to lack of available triangulation and lack of additional source signature.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2026-02-12T13:48Z. CME is also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and GOES CCOR-1. The CME is covered by a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is mostly likely related to some moving field lines best seen beyond the SW limb in SDO AIA 193 starting around 2026-02-12Z13:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement chosen due to lack of available triangulation. The source is far-sided, so no definite longitude can be visually estimated.

cmes.note: This jet-like CME is visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. It is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 due to the pylon. It is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap covering the entire event. The source of this CME appears to be a filament eruption to the NW on or just beyond the limb as seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2026-02-12T16:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the middle range between potential source longitudes (80 to 100 degrees) using available SOHO LASCO C2 and GOES CCOR-1 imagery. Longitude may vary by +/- 10 degrees.

cmes.note: CME visible to the north in GOES CCOR-1 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and to the NW in STEREO A COR2. The start time is unclear due to the faintness of the CME's leading edge. The source is likely far-sided, and no eruption signatures are seen in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME visible to the southwest in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1. The source may be some activity near the west limb as seen in SDO AIA 193 around approximately S10W80, with brightening and field line movement seen starting around 2026-02-13T03:33Z. It is not clearly associated with any active region. Field line movement can also be seen in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA. The potential source is not visible in STEREO A EUV imagery due to a data gap in STEREO A EUV imagery from 2026-02-12T17:35Z to 2026-02-13T03:55Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as potential source location.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NW in GOES CCOR-1 and the NE in STEREO A COR2. The CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real time due to a downlink gap. The source is an M1.0 flare starting at 2026-02-13T08:28Z from AR 14373 (N10W15) as best seen in SDO AIA 131. Dimming and post eruptive arcades are also best seen in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also visible in the NE quadrant of the disk from the point of view of STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and the best fit between GOES CCOR-1 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, GOES CCOR-1, and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an eruption seen from AR 14366, currently seen around N15W115 in STEREO A EUV imagery. The eruption can be seen starting around 2026-02-13T15:25Z in STEREO A EUV 195 just prior to a data gap starting at 2026-02-13T16:05Z. The eruption can also be seen beyond the limb in GOES SUVI 304 imagery starting at 2026-02-13T15:33Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement with additional imagery based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2, STEREO A COR2, and GOES CCOR-1.
Preliminary measurement based on limited available imagery using the best fit between STEREO A COR2 imagery, SOHO LASCO C2, and GOES CCOR-1 imagery in DONKI.

cmes.note: CME first seen to the SSW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-02-13T17:00Z. This CME is also seen to the SSW in SOHO LASCO C3 but is obscured by the pylon in GOES CCOR-1 and is covered by a real-time data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely related to some field line movement seen beyond the SSW limb in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2026-02-13T16:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

cmes.note: This feature is first seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting around 2026-02-13T19:36Z. It dissipates before reaching the FOV of SOHO LASCO C2 or GOES CCOR-1 and is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. There is no good source candidate on the Earth-facing disk, so the source is most likely far-sided. The CME is only seen for four frames in SOHO LASCO C2.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME only appears in four frames from SOHO LASCO C2, and the measurement has a higher degree of uncertainty.
